summary.title: Airport Surveillance System Threat Model
summary.description: Threat model for an IoT-based airport surveillance system using Raspberry Pis, MQTT (Eclipse Mosquitto), RTSP, and a web application for monitoring and controlling cameras.

cells.description: Airport security officers or administrators who interact with the system via a web browser to monitor live footage, control camera angles, and receive alerts.
A web-based interface hosted on the Raspberry Pi 4B, displaying live RTSP video streams and allowing users to send camera control commands via MQTT.
Mosquitto MQTT broker running on the Raspberry Pi 4B, facilitating publish/subscribe messaging between the web application and camera nodes.
A single-board computer within each camera node, running Motion for video streaming (RTSP) and acting as an MQTT subscriber.
A microcontroller within each camera node, controlling the servo motors based on commands from the Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W.
Mechanical components within each camera node, enabling pan and tilt functionality for the cameras.
Raspberry Pi camera module capturing live video streamed via RTSP.
Stores recorded video footage from the camera nodes, managed by the Motion application on the Raspberry Pi 4B.

text.text: User Input: Camera Commands / Video Feed & Alerts

cells.description: Commands from the Authorized User to the Web Application (e.g., adjust camera angle, view live feed), and responses (video feeds and alerts) sent back.
Camera control commands published by the Web Application to the MQTT Broker.
Commands forwarded by the MQTT Broker to the Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W in each Camera Node.
Live video data streamed from the Camera to the Web Application using the RTSP protocol.
Commands sent from the Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W to the Arduino Nano to adjust the Servo Motorsâ€™ positions.
Signals from the Arduino Nano to the Servo Motors to execute pan/tilt movements.
Recorded video footage sent from the Camera to the Recorded Footage Store.
Requests from the Web Application to the Recorded Footage Store for historical footage, and the corresponding video data returned.
An air-gapped internal network containing all system components, isolated from the public internet.

threats.title: Spoofing MQTT Client Identity
threats.description: An attacker with access to the private network spoofs the identity of a legitimate MQTT client by crafting MQTT CONNECT packets with a stolen client ID, allowing unauthorized control of camera nodes via the Eclipse Mosquitto broker. Likelihood: High (Discoverability: 7, Exploitability: 9, Awareness: 8, Intrusion Detection: 7). CAPEC-151, CWE-290, CVE-2017-7652.
threats.mitigation: Enable client ID validation in Mosquitto, use SSL/TLS with client certificates, and enforce authentication.

threats.title: Malware Injection via MQTT
threats.description: An attacker exploits the lack of nonrepudiation mechanisms in MQTT to impersonate a legitimate publisher, injecting malware into the Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W via MQTT Subscribe, potentially compromising the entire camera node. Likelihood: Medium (Discoverability: 6, Exploitability: 9, Awareness: 8, Intrusion Detection: 7). CAPEC-94, CWE-602, CVE-2018-12546.
threats.mitigation: Configure the MQTT broker to require digital signatures for all messages.

threats.title: Tampering with RTSP Video Stream
threats.description: An attacker intercepts and modifies the RTSP video stream between the Camera and Web Application, injecting false video data to deceive users. Likelihood: Medium (Discoverability: 6, Exploitability: 9, Awareness: 8, Intrusion Detection: 9). CAPEC-148, CWE-319, CVE-2019-3923.
threats.mitigation: Enable SSL/TLS for RTSP streams and implement integrity checks.

threats.title: Denial of Unauthorized Web Application Access
threats.description: An attacker with stolen credentials accesses the Web Application, performs malicious actions, and denies responsibility due to insufficient logging. Likelihood: Medium (Discoverability: 5, Exploitability: 9, Awareness: 8, Intrusion Detection: 7). CAPEC-65, CWE-778, CVE-2021-3156.
threats.mitigation: Implement robust logging and session management.

threats.title: Denial of Malicious MQTT Actions
threats.description: An attacker sends unauthorized MQTT commands and denies responsibility due to the lack of nonrepudiation and logging, making it difficult to trace the source of the attack. Likelihood: Medium (Discoverability: 6, Exploitability: 9, Awareness: 8, Intrusion Detection: 7). CAPEC-93, CWE-778, CVE-2018-12546.
threats.mitigation: Implement comprehensive logging and nonrepudiation mechanisms (e.g., digital signatures).

threats.title: Unauthorized Video Stream Access
threats.description: An attacker exploits the disabled stream authentication in the Motion application, accessing RTSP Video Streams to view live footage without authorization. Likelihood: Medium (Discoverability: 6, Exploitability: 9, Awareness: 8, Intrusion Detection: 7). CAPEC-118, CWE-200, CVE-2019-3923.
threats.mitigation: Enable stream authentication in the Motion application and use SSL/TLS encryption.

threats.title: Sniffing MQTT Cleartext Transmissions
threats.description: An attacker monitors MQTT traffic in cleartext using a sniffer, exposing camera control commands and topic structures. Likelihood: High (Discoverability: 6, Exploitability: 9, Awareness: 8, Intrusion Detection: 9). CAPEC-117, CWE-319, CVE-2018-12546.

threats.title: DDoS Attack on Raspberry Pi 4B
threats.description: An attacker launches a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack, overwhelming the Raspberry Pi 4Bâ€™s limited bandwidth, causing the MQTT Broker and Web Application to become unavailable. Likelihood: Medium (Discoverability: 7, Exploitability: 9, Awareness: 9, Intrusion Detection: 0). CAPEC-125, CWE-400, CVE-2020-13526.
threats.mitigation: Implement rate-limiting, traffic filtering, and network redundancy.

threats.title: Physical Tampering with Servo Motors
threats.description: A malicious insider physically damages the Servo Motors, disrupting their ability to adjust camera angles and creating blind spots in surveillance coverage. Likelihood: Medium (Discoverability: 8, Exploitability: 9, Awareness: 8, Intrusion Detection: 5). CAPEC-548, CWE-1263, N/A (Physical Threat).
threats.mitigation: Install tamper-proof enclosures and restrict physical access.

threats.title: Overloading Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W Memory
threats.description: An attacker floods the Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W with large MQTT messages, causing a memory overload and system crash. Likelihood: Medium (Discoverability: 5, Exploitability: 9, Awareness: 8, Intrusion Detection: 5). CAPEC-125, CWE-400, CVE-2020-13526.
threats.mitigation: Implement message size limits and rate-limiting in the MQTT broker.

threats.title: Remote Code Execution via Motion
threats.description: An attacker exploits the enabled remote control port in the Motion application to execute code with user privileges on the Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W, potentially escalating to higher access levels. Likelihood: High (Discoverability: 9, Exploitability: 9, Awareness: 8, Intrusion Detection: 5). CAPEC-233, CWE-250, CVE-2021-3156.
threats.mitigation: Disable the remote control port and harden the operating system.

threats.title: Privilege Escalation via Raspberry Pi OS
threats.description: An attacker with initial access exploits Raspberry Pi OS vulnerabilities to escalate privileges, gaining full control of the device. Likelihood: High (Discoverability: 8, Exploitability: 9, Awareness: 8, Intrusion Detection: 5). CAPEC-233, CWE-250, CVE-2021-3156.
threats.mitigation: Harden the OS, remove default credentials, and apply patches.
